user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of reply_with_area1_pages:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
reply_with_area1_pages (struct MHD_Connection *c,
                        const char *url)
{

  if (0 == strcmp (url, SEC_AREA1_URL ""))
  {
    static const char page_content[] =
      "<html><head><title>Restricted secret page</title></head>" \
      "<body>Welcome to the restricted area</body></html>";
    static const size_t page_content_len =
      (sizeof(page_content) / sizeof(char)) - 1;
    struct MHD_Response *resp;
    enum MHD_Result ret;

    resp = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (page_content_len,
                                                   page_content);
    if (NULL == resp)
      return MHD_NO;

    /* Ignore possible error when adding the header as the reply will work even
       without this header. */
    (void) MHD_add_response_header (resp, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_TYPE,
                                    "text/html");

    ret = MHD_queue_response (c, MHD_HTTP_OK, resp);
    MHD_destroy_response (resp);
    return ret;
  }
  /* If needed: add handlers for other URLs in this area */
#if 0 /* Disabled code */
  if (0 == strcmp (url, SEC_AREA1_URL "some_path/some_page"))
  {
    /* Add page creation/processing code */
  }
#endif /* Disabled code */

  /* The requested URL is unknown */
  return reply_with_page_not_found (c);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The only code region that is excluded from compilation and therefore effectively unreachable is the preprocessor-disabled block (#if 0 ... #endif). That disabled block should be investigated because it represents code present in the source that will never be executed in the build as-is.

Other fragments in the function do not need investigation for unreachable-code concerns: the initial if (0 == strcmp(...)) block is a conditional runtime branch (its body is reachable when the URL matches), its internal error-return paths (return MHD_NO) are legitimate error handling and do not make subsequent code unreachable in general, and the final return reply_with_page_not_found(c) is the normal fallback path and reachable when the first condition is not met. The static declarations and header-add/call sequences are standard and reachable within the conditional branch. No other unconditional returns or statements render following code unreachable.
